title: 107_hr1098
content: The "Maritime Policy Improvement Act of 2001" may be cited as the short title for this Act. The table of contents for this Act is provided. The "Maritime Policy Improvement Act of 2001" may be cited as the short title for this Act, and it includes various provisions related to vessels, maritime liens, certificates of documentation, and exemptions for specific ships. The Coast Guard Authorization Act of 1996 is amended to include the vessel COASTAL VENTURE. Additionally, there is an expansion of the American Merchant Marine Memorial Wall of Honor. The Congress acknowledges the historical significance of the United States Merchant Marine in serving the nation during wars since 1775, including its crucial role in gaining independence and supporting allies during World War II. President Franklin D. Roosevelt and military leaders are also recognized for their contributions. During World War II, the United States Merchant Marine played a crucial role in the victory of the allies. Over 250,000 men and women served in the Merchant Marine, facing dangers from submarines, mines, and kamikaze pilots. At least 6,830 members of the Merchant Marine lost their lives during the war. President Franklin D. Roosevelt and military leaders praised the Merchant Marine as the "Fourth Arm of Defense." During World War II, the United States Merchant Marine faced dangers from submarines, mines, armed raiders, destroyers, aircraft, and kamikaze pilots. At least 6,830 members were killed at sea, 11,000 were wounded, 604 were taken prisoner, and 1 in 32 died in the line of duty, suffering a higher percentage of war-related deaths than any other group. During World War II, the United States Merchant Marine faced significant dangers and suffered a high percentage of war-related deaths. The Merchant Marine continues to serve the United States, promoting freedom and honoring its former members through grants for a memorial wall of honor. The American Merchant Marine Veterans Memorial Committee, Inc. received a grant to add to the American Merchant Marine Memorial Wall of Honor at the Los Angeles Maritime Museum. The Federal government will cover 50% of the project costs, and $500,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2002. SEC. 5. DISCHARGE OF AGRICULTURAL CARGO RESIDUE. The discharge of agricultural cargo residue from a vessel shall be governed by the Act to Prevent Pollution from Ships. SEC. 6. RECORDING AND DISCHARGING MARITIME LIENS. Section 31343 of title 46, United States Code, is amended to allow for the recording and discharging of liens on documented vessels. The amendment specifies that the vessel must be documented or have an application for documentation filed under chapter 121. The Secretary is responsible for recording notices complying with the new regulations. The amendment to section 31343 of title 46, United States Code, allows for the recording and discharging of liens on documented vessels under chapter 121. The Secretary is required to record a notice if the person filing the claim includes a declaration confirming the accuracy of the information and sends a copy of the notice to the vessel owner. The notice for recordation must be sent to the vessel owner, individuals with recorded liens, and mortgagees of undischarged mortgages on the vessel. Declarations filed by non-individuals must be signed by authorized personnel. The notice for recordation must be sent to the vessel owner, individuals with recorded liens, and mortgagees of undischarged mortgages on the vessel. Declarations filed by non-individuals must be signed by authorized personnel. On full and final discharge of the indebtedness, a certificate of discharge must be provided to the Secretary for recording. The Secretary must record a certificate of discharge of indebtedness. District courts have jurisdiction over civil actions to declare a vessel not subject to a lien, regardless of the amount in controversy or parties' citizenship. Venue is based on where the vessel is found, claimant resides, or notice of claim of lien is recorded. Costs and attorneys fees may be awarded to the prevailing party. The notice of claim of lien recorded under subsection (b) expires 3 years after the specified date. This section does not change the law regarding maritime liens, remedies, or defenses. The establishment of a maritime lien, the remedy provided, and defenses, including defense under the doctrine of laches, are addressed in this amendment to the table of sections in title 46, United States Code. Amendment to title 46, United States Code includes changes to notice requirements for liens and approval of surrender of vessel documentation. The Secretary cannot deny approval for surrendering a vessel's documentation based solely on a recorded lien claim. Approval for vessels over 1,000 gross tons may be subject to conditions. Technical correction to the Shipping Act, 1916 is made regarding exceptions related to the Merchant Marine Act, 1936 and title 46. Effective July 1, 2002, a technical correction is made to the Shipping Act, 1916 regarding exceptions related to the Merchant Marine Act, 1936 and title 46. SEC. 7. TONNAGE OF R/V DAVIDSON. The Secretary of Transportation will determine the tonnage measurement for the vessel R/V DAVIDSON as a small passenger vessel for regulatory purposes. This applies when the vessel complies with specific requirements. SEC. 8. MISCELLANEOUS CERTIFICATES OF DOCUMENTATION. The Secretary of Transportation can issue a certificate of documentation for specific vessels for coastwise trade, including LOOKING GLASS, YANKEE, LUCKY DOG, and ENTERPRIZE. The vessels listed include LUCKY DOG, ENTERPRIZE, M/V SANDPIPER, FRITHA, PUFFIN, VICTORY OF BURNHAM, R'ADVENTURE II, ANTJA, and SKIMMER by Contour Yachts. The vessels listed include ANTJA, SKIMMER, TOKEENA, DOUBLE EAGLE2, ENCOUNTER, AJ, BARGE 10, NOT A SHOT, PRIDE OF MANY, and AMAZING GRACE with their respective registration or official numbers. The vessels PRIDE OF MANY, AMAZING GRACE, and SHEWHO have Canadian or United States official numbers. SEC. 9. EXEMPTION FOR VICTORY SHIPS. Amends Section 3302(l)(1) of title 46, United States Code to exempt the steamships SS Red Oak Victory and SS American Victory. SEC. 10. CERTIFICATE OF DOCUMENTATION FOR 3 BARGES. The Secretary of Transportation may issue a certificate of documentation for employment in the coastwise trade for specific vessels, including the former Navy deck barge JIM and the former railroad car barge HUGH. The former Navy deck barge JIM, the former railroad car barge HUGH, and the former railroad car barge TOMMY have specific dimensions. Vessels with a certificate of documentation can only be used as floating platforms for launching fireworks. SEC. 11. CERTIFICATE OF DOCUMENTATION FOR THE EAGLE. The Secretary of Transportation will issue a certificate of documentation for the vessel EAGLE for coastwise trade if owned or chartered by a State entity. The vessel EAGLE can be chartered by a State entity for coastwise trade if it meets specific operational criteria and is clearly identified as belonging to that State. SEC. 12. WAIVER FOR VESSELS IN NEW WORLD CHALLENGE RACE. Beginning April 1, 2002, 10 sailboats in the New World Challenge Race can carry non-paying guests from San Francisco and San Diego ports. This waiver expires 60 days after the race ends or on December 31, 2003. SEC. 13. VESSEL ASPHALT COMMANDER may be transferred to a foreign registry or sold to a non-US citizen.
